artist: Calligrapher: Shōdō; Calligrapher: Murase Taiitsu; Artist: Tanke Gessen
creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: standing man in profile at right, with his hands held beneath his sleeves in front of his face; man wears white kimono and black cap and has short dark hair and beard; tiny figure of old bearded man emerging from a gourd-shaped sack or jug at left; old man wears a blue kimono trimmed in grey; three inscriptions at top, with seven red seals
inscription:
(Escaping the world -- what difficulty there? / I\'ve spent much of this life in Never-Never-Land! / Inside the jug: now, is it there or not? / Who is this man lifting a whip? / Taiitsu)
(Ambition foiled -- this is what led to \"caressing and teaching;\" / He jumped into the jug and also shrank his body! / Up in the tower, how many times has he tasted the small winejug? / Ch\'ang-fang has tried hard to entertain the \"Banished Immortal.\" / - Shōdō)
Transl. by Stephen Addiss
markings: top half of image, in red: seven seals
signed: Left margin: 湘堂 {Shōdō}; LLC: 月僊 {Gessen}
text: This is a collaborative work between two artists with an additional contribution by a third artist which was added later. Originally, this work was the painting by Gessen and calligraphy by someone named Shōdō, done around 1800. In the mid-19th century, Murase Taiitsu added his poem at the top.
title: Scholar Greets a Magician
